However, the structure of hydrate under high pressure and temperature is still controversial. In this work, we report the structure of neon hydrate at high pressure and temperature. The results provide a new insight into the structure of hydrate under high pressure and temperature. This work also provides a new method to study the structure of hydrate under high pressure and temperature.

Quantum mechanics is a theory that has been very successful in describing a wide range of phenomena. However, it is not a theory that is easy to understand. In this paper, we provide a categorical approach to quantum mechanics. The approach is purely categorical and does not presuppose any analytical structure. We show that the category of Hilbert spaces and bounded linear operators provides a foundation for quantum mechanics. This approach may be of interest to researchers in the philosophy of science, in addition to those in mathematics and physics.

The Myxozoa are a group of microscopic parasites that have been hypothesized to be the result of a single evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian. Here we present a genomic and transcriptomic analysis of two distantly related species of myxozoans and a less reduced cnidarian parasite. Our results show that myxozoans are a sister group to the less reduced cnidarian parasite and that the transition from a free-living cnidarian to a parasitic myxozoan was accompanied by a dramatic reduction in genome size and gene content. Our results provide insight into the extreme evolutionary transition from a free-living cnidarian to a microscopic endoparasite. (Show more)

COVID-19, the disease caused by severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2 (SARS-CoV-2), has become a global pandemic. The virus has been shown to antagonize the antiviral action of interferon (IFN) by blocking nuclear import of transcription factors. Here we show that SARS-CoV-2 encodes a protein, Orf6, that localizes at the nuclear pore complex and interacts with the Nup98-Rae1 complex to block nuclear import of importin/karyopherin. This mechanism of viral antagonism is likely to be common among other viruses that use the Nup98-Rae1 complex to block nuclear import of transcription factors. Our study provides a molecular understanding of the viral mechanism of action and may lead to the development of antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Voltage-gated proton channels are involved in many physiological processes, such as pH homeostasis and the innate immune response. Zn2+ is an important physiological inhibitor of proton channels, but the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels is not completely understood. Here, we use the voltage clamp fluorometry technique to identify the molecular mechanism of Zn2+ inhibition of proton channels. We find that Zn2+ binds to both the activated closed and resting closed states of the proton channel, thereby inhibiting both voltage sensor motion and gate opening. These effects are similar in monomeric and dimeric proton channels, suggesting that the Zn2+-binding sites are localized within each subunit of the proton channel. Elucidating the molecular mechanism of how Zn2+ inhibits proton channels will further our understanding of proton channel function and might provide valuable information for future drug development for proton channels. Climate change will affect the productivity of the world’s major crops. In this study, we quantify the impact of climate change on maize yields and variability in the major maize-producing and -exporting countries. We find that, absent changes in temperature variability or breeding gains in heat tolerance, the coefficient of variation of maize yields will increase to values much larger than present-day values. This higher CV is due both to an increase in the standard deviation of yields and a decrease in mean yields. Our results portend rising instability in global grain trade and international grain prices, affecting especially the ∼800 million people living in extreme poverty who are most vulnerable to food price spikes. They also underscore the urgency of investments in breeding for heat tolerance. This study is important for the food security of the world and the stability of the global economy. It is also important for the agricultural sector of the countries that produce and export the most maize.

The extent to which large mammalian herbivores partition food resources is a key determinant of biodiversity in African savanna. However, the extent to which species partition food resources is unknown because of the difficulty of species-level identification of plant remains in traditional analyses. We used DNA metabarcoding to quantify diet breadth, composition, and overlap for seven abundant large mammal species in semiarid African savanna. We found that diet composition differed between all species—even pairs of grazers matched in size, digestive physiology, and location—and that dietary similarity was sometimes greater across grazing and browsing guilds than within them. Such taxonomically fine-grained diet partitioning suggests that coarse trophic categorizations may generate misleading conclusions about competition and coexistence in LMH assemblages, and that LMH diversity may be more tightly linked to plant diversity than is currently recognized. This study highlights the importance of diet composition in understanding the role of large herbivores in ecosystems. (Show more)

The COVID-19 pandemic has had a devastating impact on small businesses. We survey more than 5,800 small businesses to understand the impact of the pandemic on their operations and finances. We find that many businesses have already laid off workers and closed their doors. Businesses have widely varying beliefs about the length of the crisis. Many businesses are financially fragile, with only a few weeks of cash on hand. Finally, many businesses plan to apply for loans under the CARES Act, but anticipate problems with accessing the program.

Plastic debris is a ubiquitous problem in the ocean. However, the global load of plastic debris on the open ocean surface is still unknown. We show that the global load of floating plastic debris is on the order of tens of thousands of tons, far less than expected. This discrepancy is explained by the selective removal of plastic debris larger than 1 mm by a combination of processes yet to be discovered. This work is of fundamental importance to determine the nature and significance of the impacts of plastic pollution in the ocean.

The origin of silicon carbide (SiC) grains is one of the most intriguing questions in presolar grain research. We determined the ages of 40 large SiC grains extracted from the Murchison CM2 meteorite. We show that the grains have ages of <300 Ma and >1 Ga. The grains with ages of <300 Ma were parts of aggregates in the interstellar medium. The grains with ages of >1 Ga were parts of presolar aggregates. The results show that the interstellar medium was active ∼7 Ga ago and that the early solar system was formed in an episode of enhanced star formation. The results also show that the bulk of the cosmogenic nuclides of the grains were not produced by exposure to the early active sun.

The global fishing fleet has doubled in size since 1950, and the motorized fleet has expanded rapidly. The effective catch per unit of effort has decreased, showing the increasing pressure of fisheries on ocean resources. The effective CPUE of most countries in 2015 was a fifth of its 1950s value, which was compared with a global decline in abundance. There are signs, however, of stabilization and more effective management in recent years, with a reduction in fleet sizes in developed countries. Based on historical patterns and allowing for the slowing rate of expansion, 1 million more motorized vessels could join the global fleet by midcentury as developing countries continue to transition away from subsistence fisheries. This will challenge sustainable use of fisheries' resources.

The ability to increase the energy available to the mother is a key factor in the evolution of parental care and domestication. Here, we test the strength of this effect across a wide range of species and forms of parental care. We find that the greatest increase in reproductive output is in species that practice allonursing. Our results suggest that the ultimate factor limiting reproductive output in placental mammals is maternal metabolic power rather than resource availability. This work has implications for our understanding of the evolution of parental care and domestication. It also has implications for our understanding of the evolution of human reproduction.

Multiple system atrophy (MSA) is a sporadic neurodegenerative disorder. The disease is characterized by the accumulation of alpha-synuclein (α-syn) aggregates in affected oligodendrocytes. In this study, we show that the caspase-1 inhibitor VX-765 is able to limit the accumulation of α-syn in a mouse model of MSA. This effect was associated with a reduction of truncated α-syn and with neuroprotection. These results suggest that VX-765 could be a promising candidate to achieve disease modification in MSA. This study provides an in vivo proof of concept of the potential of VX-765 to slow down the progression of MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in humans. VX-765 is a drug that was well tolerated in a 6 wk-long phase II trial in patients with epilepsy. It is currently being tested in a phase III trial in patients with epilepsy. This study provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in MSA. This study also provides a rationale for the use of VX-765 in other synucleinopathies. (PsycINFO

The vascular endothelium is the interface between the blood and the tissues of the body. It controls the exchange of oxygen, nutrients, and waste products between the blood and the tissues. It also controls the contractility of the blood vessels and the flow of blood. The endothelium is composed of a single layer of cells that are highly specialized to perform these functions. The endothelium is able to process and integrate information from multiple sources to coordinate its responses. Here, we show that the endothelium is connected in a network of cells. We show that the network is highly connected and that the cells are able to rapidly communicate with each other. This communication is important for the coordination of the many functions of the endothelium.

The COVID-19 pandemic has been a major public health crisis. In this paper, we describe the COVIDcast API, a data source that provides a comprehensive view of the COVID-19 pandemic in the United States. The API provides a rich set of data, including traditional public health surveillance signals (cases, deaths, and hospitalizations) and many auxiliary indicators of COVID-19 activity. These are available at a fine geographic resolution (mostly at the county level) and are updated daily. The data are available in a common format through the API and accompanying R and Python software packages. We provide examples demonstrating that the auxiliary signals in the COVIDcast API present information relevant to tracking COVID activity, augmenting traditional public health reporting and empowering research and decision-making.

Potassium channels are the most abundant ion-channel family in the human body. They are involved in a wide range of physiological processes and are the target of many drugs. The selectivity filter is the narrowest part of the channel and is the site of ion conduction. It is also the site of allosteric communication between the activation and the inactivation gates. We have identified a second Threonine residue within the signature sequence of K+ channels as a crucial residue for this allosteric communication. We have shown that this residue is essential for the structural coupling between the activation and the inactivation gates. Finally, we have shown that the selectivity filter can be used as a structural switch for the allosteric communication between the activation and the inactivation gates. This work provides a structural basis for the functional coupling between the activation and the inactivation gates in potassium channels. It also provides a structural framework for the design of new drugs. (Show more)

The gut microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria, archaea, fungi, and other microbes that reside in the human body. The composition of this microbiome is important for human health and disease. In this study, we investigated the potential of anaerobic fungi to synthesize natural products that could regulate membership within the gut microbiome. We found that anaerobic fungi synthesize a diverse array of natural products, including antibiotics, antimicrobials, and bacteriocins. These results support the idea that anaerobic fungi are important producers of natural products that could be harnessed for human health and disease. This article is protected by copyright. Social dominance is a fundamental aspect of social behavior. However, whether personality traits may predispose individuals to a particular rank remains unclear. Here we show that anxiety directly influences social dominance in male outbred rats and identify an important mediating role for mitochondrial function in the nucleus accumbens. High-anxious animals that are prone to become subordinate during a social encounter with a low-anxious rat exhibit reduced mitochondrial complex I and II proteins and respiratory capacity as well as decreased ATP and increased ROS production in the nucleus accumbens. A causal link for these findings is indicated by pharmacological approaches. In a dyadic contest between anxiety-matched animals, microinfusion of specific mitochondrial complex I or II inhibitors into the nucleus accumbens reduced social rank, mimicking the low probability to become dominant observed in high-anxious individuals. Conversely, intraaccumbal infusion of nicotinamide, an amide form of vitamin B3 known to enhance brain energy metabolism, prevented the development of a subordinate status in high-anxious individuals. The design of mechanical structures with desired behaviors is of great importance for various applications. However, the use of a single material phase and heuristically developed structural patterns leads to restricted design space and potential failure to achieve specific target behaviors. Here, we propose a synthesis strategy to discover optimal composite structures that seamlessly collaborate to produce arbitrary and extreme target responses under large deformations. The structures are digitally synthesized and effectively manufactured via multimaterial fabrication. They exhibit organic shapes and motions with irregular distributions of material phases. Within the structures, different materials play distinct roles yet seamlessly collaborate to produce the target behaviors. The proposed strategy can be utilized to design function-oriented and situation-specific mechanical devices for a wide range of applications. It is also expected to be extended to other fields, such as architecture, engineering, and biology.

Hemoglobin is the oxygen-binding protein of red blood cells. The hemoglobin pattern in human blood is a reflection of the developmental stage of the blood cells. In this study, we show that the protein-coding gene IGF2BP1 is expressed in human erythroid tissues and that its expression is developmentally regulated. We demonstrate that IGF2BP1 can reprogram the hemoglobin pattern in human erythroid cells. This suggests that IGF2BP1 may be a potential target for the treatment of hemoglobinopathies.

Cancer is the leading cause of death worldwide. Despite recent advances in cancer treatment, the majority of patients do not respond to therapy. In this study, we identified a mechanism of resistance to ferroptosis in cancer cells, which is mediated by the mTORC1-SREBP1-SCD1 pathway. We also identified a potential therapeutic strategy for cancer treatment, which involves the combination of mTORC1 inhibition with ferroptosis induction. Our findings may lead to the development of new cancer therapies. (Show more)

Hypertension is a major risk factor for heart failure. The underlying mechanisms of hypertension-induced heart failure are complex and not fully understood. Here, we show that the major classes of L-type Ca2+ channel blockers (LCCBs) activate STIM1, which in turn activates ORAI channels and promotes vascular remodeling. Our findings indicate that LCCBs should be used with caution in patients with advanced hypertension and/or heart failure. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for the treatment of hypertension-induced heart failure. This study also provides a rationale for the use of LCCBs in the treatment of hypertension in the elderly population.

The Northwest Forest Plan (NWFP) was a landmark policy that changed the way forests were managed in the Pacific Northwest. We show that the NWFP had little effect on the conservation of older-forest–associated birds. However, it did halt the decline of early-seral–associated birds. This suggests that the NWFP was successful in its goal of halting the loss of older forests. However, the policy failed to reverse the decline of older-forest–associated bird populations.

Antibiotic resistance is a major threat to global health. Therefore, the development of new antibiotics is urgently needed. Here, we present a rational design approach to identify new antibiotics. The approach is based on computational predictions of membrane permeability, binding affinity to the ribosome, and solubility. We show that the approach is successful in identifying new antibiotics that are active against antibiotic-resistant pathogens. The best candidate identified by us is up to 56 times more active than telithromycin, a clinically used antibiotic, and is more accessible than telithromycin. The approach can be used to identify new antibiotics for other pathogens of global health concern. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Deep convolutional neural networks have been successfully applied to many image-processing problems in recent works. However, the number of trainable parameters in these networks is often large, which makes it difficult to train the networks with a large number of training samples. In this work, we introduce a network architecture that is able to achieve accurate results with relatively few parameters. The proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with a small number of trainable parameters and automatically adapts to different problems. We compare results of the proposed network architecture with popular existing architectures for several segmentation problems, showing that the proposed architecture is able to achieve accurate results with fewer parameters. The proposed architecture is also easier to implement, train, and apply in practice.

The transport of moisture in the tropics is a critical process for the global energy budget and on geologic timescales, has markedly influenced continental landscapes, migratory pathways, and biological evolution. We present a continuous, first-of-its-kind 1.3-My record of continental hydroclimate and lake-level variability derived from drill core data from Lake Malawi, East Africa. We observe dramatic shifts in effective moisture, resulting in large-scale changes in one of the world’s largest lakes and most diverse freshwater ecosystems. Results show evidence for 24 lake level drops of more than 200 m during the Late Quaternary, including 15 lowstands when water levels were more than 400 m lower than modern. A dramatic shift is observed at the Mid-Pleistocene Transition (MPT), consistent with far-field climate forcing, which separates vastly different hydroclimate regimes before and after ∼800,000 years ago. The use of electronic devices for reading and entertainment has become increasingly popular. However, the impact of such devices on sleep is unknown. Here we show that reading an electronic book on a light-emitting device phase-delays the circadian clock, acutely suppresses melatonin, and has important implications for understanding the impact of such technologies on sleep, performance, health, and safety. These results have implications for the design of electronic devices and the timing of their use before bedtime. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Younger Dryas (YDB) chronostratigraphic boundary is marked by a cooling of ∼6 °C. One or more bolide impacts are hypothesized to have triggered the YDB cooling. In support of this hypothesis, varying peak abundances of magnetic grains with iridium and magnetic microspherules have been reported at the YDB. We show that the osmium (Os) isotopic composition of the YDB magnetic grains/microspherules is consistent with terrestrial Os, whereas the Os in the YDB magnetic grains/microspherules from Belgium is likely derived from a meteorite. The YDB spherules are 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America. The 187Os/188Os ratios of the spherules and their leachates are often low, but Os in these objects is likely terrestrially derived. The rare earth element patterns and Sr and Nd isotopes of the spherules indicate that their source lies in 1.5-Ga Quebecia terrain in the Grenville Province of northeastern North America.

The role of CTLA-4 in the immune system is controversial. Here, we show that CTLA-4 is essential for the development of autoimmunity in adult mice. We also show that CTLA-4 deficiency can be used to study the role of CTLA-4 in the development of autoimmunity in the context of the immune system. This study provides a better understanding of the role of CTLA-4 in the immune system and its importance in the development of autoimmunity.

Beetles are the most speciose group of animals, but the origin of their diversity remains poorly understood. We used a combination of genomic and fossil data to show that the evolution of beetles and their plant-feeding habits are linked to the evolution of genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. Our results suggest that the evolution of beetles was driven by multiple factors, including low extinction rates over a long evolutionary history, the codiversification of beetles and plants, and adaptive radiations of specialized herbivores following convergent horizontal transfers of microbial genes encoding enzymes that digest plant cell walls. Our results have implications for our understanding of the evolution of animal diversity and the origin of plant cell walls. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. We demonstrated that our algorithm can improve the antibody’s activity against multiple variants, including Delta. Our results suggest that this approach can be used to improve the effectiveness of other proteins, such as those in vaccines and therapeutics. Our optimized antibodies can potentially be developed into antibody drug candidates for current and emerging SARS-CoV-’2 variants.

The extent to which larger populations enhance cumulative cultural evolution (CCE) is a topic of intense debate. We report a large-scale experiment (n = 543) that investigates the CCE of technology (paper planes and their flight distances) using a transmission-chain design. We find that larger populations do not enhance CCE, and that it may be only under certain specific conditions that larger population sizes enhance CCE. Our results have implications for the evolution of technology and the origins of culture. They also have implications for the design of experiments that investigate the role of culture in the evolution of intelligence.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia. The strongest genetic risk factor for AD is the apoE allele. APOE is a large protein that has three common isoforms in humans, E2, E3, and E4. APOE E4 allele is associated with ∼12-fold increased risk for AD, whereas APOE E2 allele is associated with ∼twofold decreased risk. Here, we report a novel role for APOE in controlling the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. We also found that APOE E4 allele is associated with increased accumulation of senescent synapses in the brain, which may contribute to AD pathogenesis. These studies reveal a novel allele-dependent role for APOE in regulating the rate of synapse pruning by astrocytes. They also suggest the hypothesis that APOE E4 may contribute to AD pathogenesis by accelerating the rate of accumulation of senescent synapses. This hypothesis is supported by the recent finding that APOE E4 is associated with increased levels of a protein that mediates synapse degeneration. The Earth's inner core is a solid core with a diameter of about 1,200 km. It is the densest part of the Earth. The origin of the inner core is still a mystery. One of the most important questions is how the inner core formed. In this study, we show that the nucleation of the inner core is more likely to be a two-step process. The first step is the nucleation of the bcc phase of iron. The second step is the nucleation of the hcp phase. This mechanism reduces the required undercooling of iron nucleation, which provides a key factor in solving the inner core nucleation paradox. The two-step nucleation scenario of the inner core also opens an avenue for understanding the structure and anisotropy of the present inner core. (Show more)

Marijuana is the most commonly used illicit drug in the United States. Although the drug is illegal, it is widely available. The drug’s effects on the brain are not well understood. Here, we show that the brain’s response to the drug is altered in people who abuse marijuana.

Language is a uniquely human skill. It is also the most complex cognitive system we know of. How the brain processes language is a central question in cognitive science. Here, we use a state-of-the-art computational model to study the brain’s response to language. We find that the model’s neural fit and fit to behavior are both strongly correlated with the model’s accuracy on the next-word prediction task. Model architecture appears to substantially contribute to neural fit. These results provide computational evidence that predictive processing fundamentally shapes the language comprehension mechanisms in the brain. They also suggest that the brain may use predictive coding algorithms to solve language comprehension. This is a major advance in our understanding of the brain.

Deep learning (DL) has been a major breakthrough in machine learning. However, it is still a black box, and it is not clear why it works. In this paper, we show that the success of DL is due to the existence of a small number of stable algorithms. We prove that there are problems in scientific computing where one can prove the existence of stable algorithms, but there is no algorithm that can solve the problem. This is a new type of proof, and it is a major step toward understanding the success of DL.

The COVID-19 pandemic is a global tragedy. The scientific community has been working hard to understand the virus and its spread. One of the most influential studies in this field is a classic experiment published in 1972. It is often cited as evidence that people are unable to understand exponential growth. However, its design flaws were not noticed at the time and are only now being discussed.

Leprosy is a chronic disease that can be cured with antibiotics. However, the causative agent is still unknown. Here we report the genome sequence of a human pathogen, M. lepromatosis, which is associated with a reactional state known as Lucio's phenomenon. We also show that M. lepromatosis and M. leprae, the two leprosy bacilli, are remarkably conserved and still cause similar pathologic conditions. This study provides a better understanding of the evolution of leprosy and may lead to the discovery of new drug targets. (Show more)

Entanglement and thermodynamics are two of the most fundamental concepts in physics. They are also the two concepts that are most difficult to study in quantum systems. Here, we show that the entanglement dynamics can be completely understood in the space–time scaling limit. This result is a major step toward a complete understanding of the thermodynamics of quantum systems.

COVID-19 is a pandemic that has caused millions of deaths worldwide. The only currently available vaccine against COVID-19 is the messenger RNA (mRNA) vaccine, which requires cold storage and is not suitable for mass vaccination. Here, we describe a live attenuated SARS-CoV-2 vaccine that can be stored at room temperature and is suitable for mass vaccination. This vaccine is temperature sensitive in vitro but robustly grows at the human body temperature. In addition, the vaccine is codon optimized to increase its translation efficiency and is devoid of the viral spike protein cleavage site, which is known to be immunodominant. The vaccine is highly protective in a relevant hamster model and can be manufactured in large quantities. These features support its potential use in mass vaccination programs. Plague is a disease with a long history of human suffering and mortality. It is also a disease that can be transmitted by multiple transmission pathways. In this study, we use a compartmental model to investigate the historical spread of plague in Europe. We find that human ectoparasites were the primary vector for plague during the Second Pandemic, including the Black Death. This study challenges the assumption that plague in Europe was predominantly spread by rats.

The evolution of brain size has been used as a proxy to study the evolution of cognitive ability. However, this approach is biased because of the influence of other factors, such as the evolution of body size. Here, we show that the evolution of brain size can be biased by other factors. We propose a new approach to study the evolution of brain size by using the number of neurons instead of brain mass. We show that the evolution of brain size is biased by other factors, such as the evolution of body size.

Cancer is a disease of the cell, and the cell is a complex organelle. Cancer cells often have a dysfunctional cell nucleus, but they also have dysfunctional mitochondria. The mitochondrion is the site of respiration, and it is also the site of many of the metabolic pathways that are deregulated in cancer. This study shows that a protein that is broadly considered to be an anticancer target, TRAP1 (TNF receptor-associated protein), is also a regulator of mitochondrial metabolism and function. These data suggest that TRAP1 may be a tumor suppressor.

Actin filaments are the main cytoskeletal elements that mediate cell motility. They are also the targets of the ADF/cofilin family of proteins, which are key regulators of cell motility. However, how ADF/cofilin proteins sever actin filaments in a physiological context, where filaments are interconnected and under mechanical stress, remains unclear. Here, we use single-molecule, single-filament, and filament network techniques to study the action of ADF/cofilin in different mechanical situations. We find that ADF/cofilin enhances severing of filaments that are held between two anchoring points, thereby constraining their twist. A simple model, which faithfully recapitulates our experimental observations, indicates that the ADF/cofilin-induced twist enhances severing by 100-fold. We propose that this mechanochemical mechanism is critical to boost ADF/cofilin’s ability to sever highly connected filament networks in cells. Our findings have implications for our understanding of ADF/cofilin function in cells and for the design of new drugs. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Fructose, a common sweetener found in many foods and beverages, is a popular choice for dieters. However, the effects of fructose on brain and behavior are unclear. In this study, we show that ingestion of fructose relative to glucose results in greater brain activation to food cues and greater hunger and desire for food. These findings suggest that fructose may promote feeding behavior. Our results have implications for the design of future studies and for the development of interventions to reduce the consumption of fructose. (PsycINFO Database Record

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement. However, the distribution of ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous across the island, suggesting that the settlement happened in several independent waves. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

We show that people’s emotions can be influenced by the emotions of others on Facebook. This is a form of emotional contagion, which has been observed in laboratory experiments but not in the real world. We show that the influence of others’ emotions is not limited to in-person interaction, and that it can be positive. This work has implications for our understanding of the role of social media in our lives.

Messenger RNAs (mRNAs) are the primary targets of posttranscriptional regulation. One of the most common modifications in coding regions is pseudouridine (Ψ), which can have a profound impact on protein synthesis. Here, we show that the presence of Ψ in an mRNA codon can impede the addition of amino acids to the growing peptide chain and the activation of the elongation factor EF-Tu. We also show that the presence of Ψ can promote the synthesis of multiple peptide products from a single mRNA sequence in the cell. These findings suggest that the ribosome can encounter Ψ in mRNA sequences and that this can have a modest impact on protein synthesis. Our work provides insight into the impact of mRNA modifications on protein synthesis and may have implications for the design of mRNA-based therapeutics. (Show more)

The feeling that one’s life is filled with worthwhile activities is fundamental to human flourishing and subjective well-being. Here, we show that this feeling is associated with a wide range of positive outcomes, including better health, social engagement, and use of time. These findings have implications for the design of interventions to promote healthy aging.

The evolution of larger body sizes in aquatic mammals is a well-known pattern in biology. However, the underlying drivers of this pattern remain unclear. Here, we use a quantitative model to show that the evolution of an aquatic lifestyle is driving three of the four extant aquatic mammal clades toward a size attractor at ∼500 kg. This attractor is consistent with energetic constraints on body size in the aquatic realm. Our results provide a quantitative framework for understanding the evolution of body size in aquatic mammals and other aquatic organisms. This framework can be extended to other ecological and evolutionary questions in aquatic biology.

The common cold is one of the most common and economically devastating diseases in the world. The mechanisms that allow a virus to replicate more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature are poorly understood. We show that the mouse-adapted rhinovirus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity than at body temperature. We also show that the virus replicates more efficiently at the cool temperatures of the nasal cavity because of a less efficient antiviral defense response of infected cells at cool temperature. These findings have implications for the development of antiviral therapies for the common cold. (PsycINFO Database Record

Bacteria are constantly exposed to a variety of environmental signals. Some of these signals are sensed by the cell to trigger a response, while others are ignored. In this study, we show that the bacteria Pseudomonas aeruginosa uses the activity of its pili to sense the presence of surfaces. This signal is then used to regulate the activity of the pili, thereby promoting the attachment of the bacteria to surfaces. This mechanism is important for the survival of the bacteria, as it allows them to attach to surfaces in the environment, where they can proliferate and cause infections.

The use of pesticides in agriculture has increased dramatically over the last decades. However, the impact of pesticides on the environment is still poorly understood. We show that the biological integrity of global water resources is at a substantial risk. Our results suggest the need for worldwide improvements to current pesticide regulations and agricultural pesticide application practices and for intensified research efforts on the presence and effects of pesticides under real-world conditions.

SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, has spread globally and is responsible for millions of deaths. The virus has been documented in many animal species, but the extent of the spillover events and the role of animals in the pandemic are not well understood. Here, we report the detection of SARS-CoV-2 in free-living deer. We also show that the virus has spread between deer and humans. These findings have important implications for the long-term persistence of the pandemic.

The world is moving toward a more sustainable energy future. This paper examines the proliferation of large dams in developing countries and the importance of incorporating climate change into considerations of whether to build a dam. We also examine the overestimation of benefits and underestimation of costs along with changes that are needed to address the legitimate social and environmental concerns of people living in areas where dams are planned. Finally, we propose innovative solutions that can move hydropower toward sustainable practices together with solar, wind, and other renewable sources.

Alzheimer’s disease (AD) is the most common cause of dementia, and the amyloid-β (Aβ) protein is the primary pathological hallmark of the disease. However, the immune response in AD is often attributed to microglial activation in response to Aβ plaques. Here, we show that neurons are also capable of mounting an inflammatory response to Aβ, even in the absence of plaques. We demonstrate that the Aβ-burdened neuron is a primary proinflammatory agent, implicating the intraneuronal accumulation of Aβ as a significant immunological component in the AD pathogenesis. Our findings have important implications for the development of novel therapeutic strategies for AD. © 2016 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The domestic chicken (Gallus gallus domesticus) is one of the most widespread domesticated species in the world. However, the earliest evidence for its economic exploitation is still unknown. We present a faunal analysis of the Hellenistic site of Maresha, Israel, which shows that the exploitation of chickens was widespread and economically important in the Southern Levant during the fourth–second centuries B.C.E. We further show that the adoption of chickens in European husbandry was preceded by at least a century by the finds in the Southern Levant.

The folding of a protein is a complex process. It is not a single reaction but a sequence of steps. The steps are not independent but are coupled to each other. The steps are not random but are guided by the protein’s structure. The steps are not sequential but can occur simultaneously. The steps are not irreversible but can be reversed. The steps are not unique but can be many. The steps are not known. This paper describes a step that is known to be one of the steps.

Dinucleoside tetraphosphates (Np4) are alarmones that accumulate in response to stress. In bacteria, Np4 decapping is critical for the rapid degradation of Np4-capped RNAs, which are often produced in response to stress. Here, we show that the RNA pyrophosphohydrolase RppH, which is inactivated by Np4, is the predominant decapping enzyme in cells experiencing stress. We demonstrate that RppH decapsulates Np4-capped RNAs by a mechanism distinct from the one it uses to decapsulate other RNAs. This enzyme prefers Np4-capped RNAs as substrates, generating triphosphorylated RNA as the primary product of decapping. The unconventional manner in which RppH recognizes Np4-capped 5′ ends and its differential impact on the rates at which such termini are deprotected as a prelude to RNA degradation could have major consequences for reprogramming gene expression during disulfide stress. Sepsis is a life-threatening condition that is associated with high mortality. The mechanisms involved in the immunosuppression that occurs during sepsis are not fully understood. We hypothesized that increasing arginine availability would restore T cell function and decrease immunosuppression. We demonstrated that citrulline administration was more efficient than arginine in increasing arginine plasma levels and restoring T cell mitochondrial function and proliferation while reducing immunosuppression. Because there is no specific therapeutic strategy to restore immune function after sepsis, we believe that our study provides evidence for developing citrulline-based clinical studies in sepsis. This study may also have implications for other conditions in which immunosuppression is a major factor in the disease progression. © 2016 American Association for the Advancement of Science.

The biomass of the biosphere is a fundamental quantity that is essential for understanding the structure and dynamics of the ecosystem. However, a global, quantitative view of how the biomass of different taxa compare with one another is still lacking. Here, we assemble the overall biomass composition of the biosphere, establishing a census of the ≈550 Gt C of biomass distributed among all of the kingdoms of life. We show that the biomass of humans is an order of magnitude higher than that of all wild mammals combined. We also highlight the historical impact of humanity on the global biomass of prominent taxa, including mammals, fish, and plants. Our results provide a global view of the biomass of the biosphere and its distribution among the kingdoms of life. Self-organized criticality (SOC) is a phenomenon in nature and in physics, where a system evolves in time and space, and the system’s dynamics become “critical” when the system is perturbed. SOC systems are characterized by a power-law distribution of the system’s activity. The most famous example of SOC is the sandpile model. In this paper, we report on our discovery of a tropical model with self-organized criticality (SOC) behavior. Our model is continuous, in contrast to all known models of SOC, and is a certain scaling limit of the sandpile model. We describe how our model is related to pattern formation and proportional growth phenomena and discuss the dichotomy between continuous and discrete models in several contexts. Our aim in this context is to present an idealized tropical toy model, requiring further investigation.

Diamond is a promising material for many applications, including quantum devices. However, it is brittle and has a narrow bandgap. Here, we show that diamond can be metallized reversibly by strain engineering. This opens up opportunities to tailor its properties for applications.

The discovery of a new class of antifungal peptides is of great interest to the scientific community and the agricultural industry. However, the structural basis of their antifungal activity and the mode of action against plant fungal pathogens is largely unknown. Here, we report the structure of a unique antifungal peptide from a model legume, and demonstrate its potent fungicidal activity against multiple plant fungal pathogens. We also show that this peptide can bind to phosphoinositides and disrupt the fungal cell wall. This work provides a structural basis for the antifungal activity of this class of peptides and paves the way for future development of this class of peptides as a spray-on fungistat/fungicide. The male–female reproductive axis is a fundamental system in biology. However, the extent of molecular continuity between males and females is largely unknown. Here, we show that the proteome of Drosophila sperm undergoes substantial compositional changes after being transferred to the female reproductive tract. We also show that female-derived proteins begin to associate with sperm immediately after mating and comprise nearly 20% of the postmating sperm proteome following 4 d of storage in the female reproductive tract. Our research provides a comprehensive characterization of sperm proteome dynamics and expands our understanding of the critical process of sperm–FRT interactions. This work may also have implications for the study of other species with internal fertilization. (Show more)

Von Willebrand factor (VWF) is a large protein that binds to platelets, helping them stick to the vessel wall and stop bleeding. Mutations in VWF cause a common bleeding disorder, von Willebrand disease (VWD). We show that force can be used to switch the VWF molecule to a second state that binds platelets more strongly. This mechanism explains the effects of mutations in VWF and may be used to treat bleeding. This work is important because it shows that force can be used to switch proteins, which is a key step in understanding how cells work. It also shows that the same force can be used to switch different proteins. This work is also important because it shows that the same force can be used to switch different proteins.

The human microbiome is a complex ecosystem of bacteria that has been the focus of intense study for the past decade. However, the viral component of the microbiome has been more difficult to study, due to the lack of a comprehensive database. This study provides a comprehensive database for human-associated viruses, which can be used to study the impact of viruses on human health. We find that viruses are strongly associated with many diseases, and that these associations are not explained by known bacteria–disease associations. This database will be a valuable resource for the scientific community for years to come.

Aerosol–cloud interaction (ACI) is one of the most important processes in the climate system. However, it is difficult to be well represented in current climate models. This is due to the complexity of ACI processes and the lack of observational capability. Here, we introduce a new technique, the dual-field-of-view high-spectral-resolution lidar (HSRL), to simultaneously observe aerosols and clouds. This technique can provide high-resolution and simultaneous observations of aerosols and clouds, especially water cloud microphysical properties. We use this technique to investigate the interactions between aerosol loading and water cloud microphysical properties. The results show that the ACI process is more complex than previously thought. This technique is expected to represent a significant step forward in characterizing ACI. It will be a significant contributor to the ACI investigations. This article is protected by copyright. The temperature of Earth’s surface has been a subject of debate for more than a century. The temperature of the surface of the Earth is important for understanding the origin and evolution of life. Here we present a method for determining the temperature of the surface of the Earth in the past.

Potassium channels are important for the normal function of the heart, brain, and kidneys. They are also involved in many diseases, such as heart failure, epilepsy, and hypertension. The large-conductance calcium-activated potassium (BK) channel is a major contributor to the resting membrane potential of the heart. It is also involved in the regulation of blood pressure and heart rate. The BK channel normally shows no C-type inactivation, but we found that it can exhibit slow C-type inactivation. We propose that the BK channel’s normal closing may represent an early conformational stage of C-type inactivation. This study may provide a new perspective for the study of ion channels and their diseases. (Show more)

Malaria is a disease that affects millions of people worldwide. The parasite exploits the host cell to facilitate invasion. Here, we show that the malaria parasite alters the biophysical properties of the host cell to facilitate invasion. This is a major change in our understanding of the malaria parasite and could have implications for the development of new antimalarial therapies.

Influenza virus is a major cause of respiratory disease in humans and animals. In this study, we show that mice housed in low humidity are more susceptible to severe disease following respiratory challenge with influenza virus. We also show that low humidity impairs mucociliary clearance, innate antiviral defense, and tissue repair. Moreover, disease exacerbated by low humidity was ameliorated in caspase-1/11–deficient Mx1 mice, independent of viral burden. These results indicate that exposure to dry air impairs host defense against influenza infection, reduces tissue repair, and inflicts caspase-dependent disease pathology. Our findings provide insights into the pathogenesis of influenza virus infection and disease, and may inform the development of strategies to mitigate the impact of influenza virus in humans and animals. The brain is thought to build a tree-like structure of syntactic relations between words. However, whether and how the brain builds such a structure remains unknown. Here, we show that the brain’s activity increases with each successive word in a sentence but decreases suddenly whenever words can be merged into a phrase. This pattern of activity is consistent with a merge operation that applies equally to linguistic objects of arbitrary complexity. More superficial models of language, based on sequential transition probabilities, only captured activity in the posterior middle temporal gyrus. Our results provide initial intracranial evidence for the neurophysiological reality of the merge operation postulated by linguists and suggest that the brain compresses syntactically well-formed sequences of words into a hierarchy of nested phrases. This process may be critical for language comprehension and production.

The canonical Wnt pathway is a major signaling pathway in vertebrates. It is important for development and disease. Axin is a key component of the pathway. We show that the two forms of Axin are similar at the protein level but differ in their regulation. This difference can be used to control the activity of the pathway in different tissues.

Obesity is a major health concern, and the mechanisms that promote overeating are poorly understood. Here we present a characterization of a brain circuit that may promote overeating. We show that electrical stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus induces vigorous eating in sated mice. We also show that this effect is blocked by dopamine receptor antagonists and lesions of the ventral tegmental area or the dopamine neurons in the substantia nigra. Finally, we show that stimulation of the lateral hypothalamus can induce eating in a region of the lateral hypothalamus that is distant from the site of stimulation. This circuit may contribute to overeating and contribute to the development of obesity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The Amazon is the world’s most important tropical forest, but it is also one of the most threatened. Remote-sensed deforestation alerts are a promising tool for forest monitoring, but they rarely reach the most directly affected communities in time to deter deforestation. We study a community monitoring program that facilitated transfer of early deforestation alerts from the Global Forest Watch network to indigenous communities in the Peruvian Amazon and trained and incentivized community members to patrol forests in response to those alerts. Our results suggest that the program reduced tree cover loss, but the estimated effects from the experiment are imprecise. Should our findings be replicated elsewhere, they imply that externally facilitated community-based monitoring protocols that combine remote-sensed early deforestation alerts with training and incentives for monitors could contribute to sustainable forest management.

Animals use their hearing to perceive the world around them. The auditory organs of animals are diverse in structure and function, but all are part of the body of the animal. Here, we show that hearing in the orb-weaving spider Larinioides sclopetarius is not constrained by the organism’s body but is extended through outsourcing hearing to its extended phenotype, the proteinaceous, self-manufactured orb web. The web acts as a hyperacute acoustic antenna to capture the sound-induced air particle movements that approach the maximum physical efficiency better than the acoustic responsivity of all previously known eardrums. By outsourcing its acoustic sensors to its web, the spider is released from body size constraints and permits the araneid spider to increase its sound-sensitive surface area enormously, up to 10,000 times greater than the spider itself. The spider also enables the flexibility to functionally adjust and regularly regenerate its external "eardrum" according to its needs. The outsourcing and supersizing of auditory function in spiders provide unique features for studying extended and regenerative sensing and designing novel acoustic flow detectors for precise fluid dynamic measurement and manipulation. Neuroblastoma is the most common solid tumor of childhood. It is a heterogeneous disease with a large number of different molecular subtypes. In the last years, it was shown that some of these molecular subtypes are driven by mutations in the kinase anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK). In this study, we show that zebrafish ALK/ALKL receptors are activated by zebrafish ALKALs. This finding is important because it allows studying the role of ALK/ALKL receptors in vivo.

Plague is one of the most devastating diseases in human history, and its emergence from a Yersinia pseudotuberculosis-like progenitor is a key event in the history of human disease. However, the number of ancient Y. pestis genomes is too small to explore its diversity during this critical period of development. Here, we present 17 Y. pestis genomes from 5,000 to 2,500 y BP, which allowed us to explore correlations between temporal, geographical, and genetic distance. Our results suggest a nonflea-adapted and potentially extinct single lineage that persisted over millennia without significant parallel diversification, accompanied by rapid dispersal across continents throughout this period. Together, these data reveal the dynamic nature of plague’s formative years in terms of its early evolution and ecology. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

This work examined the role of the culturally endorsed form of masculinity (hegemonic masculinity) in men’s and women’s support for Donald Trump in the 2016 and 2020 American presidential elections. Consistent with our theoretical backdrop, we found that men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity predicted voting for and evaluations of Trump, over and above political party affiliation, gender, race, and education. These effects held when controlling for respondents’ trust in the government, in contrast to a populist explanation of support for Trump. The findings highlight the importance of psychological examinations of masculinity as a cultural ideology to understand how men’s and women’s endorsement of hegemonic masculinity legitimizes patriarchal dominance and reinforces gender, race, and class-based hierarchies via candidate support. Soil organic carbon (SOC) sequestration in agricultural systems is a critical strategy for mitigating climate change. However, the management practices that can increase SOC storage in the world’s grasslands remain unclear. We show that soil health management practices that increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, such as incorporating legumes and applying manure, can increase SOC storage in annual cropping systems. These practices also increase soil microbial biomass and diversity, but to a lesser extent, in perennial pastures. In contrast, conventional tillage and monocropping with annual tillage decreased SOC storage. These results highlight the importance of soil health management practices in increasing SOC storage in grasslands worldwide. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for a global system to identify and prioritize viruses with the potential to spillover and spread in humans. We developed a framework to identify risk factors for zoonotic virus spillover and spread in humans and used this to rank the zoonotic potential of 887 wildlife viruses. We validated the framework using data from virus discovery projects and public records of virus detections around the world. The resulting ranking of zoonotic potential can be used by policy makers and health scientists to inform research and public health interventions for prevention and rapid control of disease outbreaks. SpillOver is a living, interactive database that can be refined over time to continue to improve the quality and public availability of information on viral threats to human health. This resource will be essential for the global community to prepare for and respond to future viral threats.

Nectar is a reward that many flowering plants offer to pollinators for reproduction. The color of nectar is an important trait that can attract pollinators. Here, we show that the color of the red nectar of Nesocodon mauritianus is derived from a previously undescribed alkaloid. We also show that this alkaloid is attractive to a vertebrate pollinator. This work identifies a convergently evolved trait in two species of plants that are pollinated by hummingbirds. This suggests that the red nectar trait is a simple and effective way to attract pollinators.

The history of Europe is marked by a series of migrations and invasions. However, the history of the population during the period between these events is largely unknown. Here we present a genome-wide analysis of a group of women from Bavaria, Germany, who had been deformed by cranial cranial deformation. Our results indicate that these women had a genetic ancestry that was not present in the rest of the population. In addition, we show that many alleles associated with recent positive selection were already at modern-like frequencies in European populations ∼1,500 years ago. This study provides new insights into the history of Europe.

Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) currently spreads in humans and causes ∼36% fatality in infected patients. Believed to have originated from bats, MERS-CoV is genetically related to bat coronaviruses HKU4 and HKU5. To understand how bat coronaviruses transmit to humans, we investigated the receptor usage and cell entry activity of the virus-surface spike proteins of HKU4 and HKU5. We found that dipeptidyl peptidase 4 (DPP4), the receptor for MERS-CoV, is also the receptor for HKU4, but not HKU5. Despite sharing a common receptor, MERS-CoV and HKU4 spikes demonstrated functional differences. These results establish DPP4 as a functional receptor for HKU4 and host cellular proteases as a host range determinant for HKU4. They also suggest that DPP4-recognizing bat coronaviruses threaten human health because of their spikes’ capability to adapt to human cells for cross-species transmissions. The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for rapid, accurate, and scalable diagnostics in resource-scarce settings. Here, we show that metagenomic next-generation sequencing (mNGS) can be used to identify a variety of vector-borne, zoonotic, and emerging pathogens responsible for undifferentiated fevers in a periurban population in Cambodia. This approach can be used to identify the regional pathogen landscape and mitigate the impact of emerging and reemerging diseases. The human genome is replicated in a process that is highly similar to that of S. cerevisiae. However, the mechanisms that ensure the fidelity of replication and the stability of the replication machinery are different. In this study, we developed unique kinetic assays to measure the processivity and stability of the human replication machinery. We found that the human replication machinery is significantly less stable than its yeast counterpart. This has important implications for the fidelity of replication and the dynamics of the replication process.
The origin of life is one of the most important questions in biology. In this paper, we report the first demonstration of the ability of RNA to replicate itself.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to study. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We then use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and other types of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

COVID-19 is a severe pneumonia caused by the novel coronavirus. The clinical manifestations are diverse, and the mortality rate is high. The treatment is mainly supportive. In this study, we found that tocilizumab, which targets the interleukin-6 pathway, can reduce the mortality of severe and critical COVID-19 patients. It is an effective treatment to reduce mortality.

Fungi are ubiquitous in the environment and in the human body. They are also important pathogens. In this study, we report the discovery of a fungal natural product that binds copper. This discovery has implications for the role of copper in fungal physiology and for the role of fungi in the human body.

The formation of silica in the Martian environment is a key to understanding the origin of the Martian surface. The detection of tridymite in a Martian drill sample is a significant step forward in this understanding.

Frost damage is a major threat to plant productivity and a significant economic burden to agriculture and forestry. However, the geographic distribution of frost events is poorly understood. We show that the geographic distribution of frost events is strongly associated with the evolutionary history of the species. Our findings can inform decision-making in land management, forestry, agriculture, and insurance policy.

Th17 cells are a major component of the inflammatory response in certain types of inflammatory bowel disease. However, the functional significance of this response is not well understood. Here we show that Th17 cells can directly contribute to the development of classic Th1 cells and that this dual role is critical for the development of colitis. These results have implications for the treatment of inflammatory bowel disease.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a fatal neurodegenerative disease with no cure. The disease is caused by mutations in genes encoding motor neuron proteins, and the disease process is poorly understood. We report a method to convert adult human fibroblasts from living ALS patients to induced neuronal progenitor cells and subsequent differentiation into astrocytes. This enables rapid disease modeling and high-throughput drug screening to alleviate astrocyte-derived toxicity. This method will be useful for studying the disease process and developing therapeutics for ALS. It will also be useful for studying other neurodegenerative diseases, such as Huntington’s disease, spinocerebellar ataxia, and frontotemporal dementia. This method will also be useful for studying the role of astrocytes in other diseases, such as stroke and epilepsy.

The gut microbiota of arthropod vectors is an important factor in the transmission of infectious diseases. However, the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector’s microbiota are poorly understood. Here, we show that the human pathogen Anaplasma phagocytophilum induces ticks to express antifreeze glycoprotein, which alters the composition of the tick gut microbiota and facilitates the pathogen’s colonization of the vector. We also show that antifreeze glycoprotein alters the permeability of the gut barrier and the integrity of the peritrophic matrix, two critical obstacles for Anaplasma colonization. These data elucidate the mechanisms by which a human pathogen exploits an arthropod antibacterial protein to alter the gut microbiota and more effectively colonize the vector. This work provides insight into the mechanisms by which pathogens influence the composition of the vector’s microbiota and may lead to the development of new strategies to control vector-borne diseases. Birds are one of the most successful animal lineages. However, the origin of the modern avian bauplan is still a matter of debate. Here, we describe a new basal member of the short-tailed bird group, which adds important information about the evolution of the modern avian bauplan.

The climate system is a complex system, and it is difficult to understand the climate system without understanding the role of water vapor. In this paper, we show that water vapor in the stratosphere plays an important role in the climate system.

Vertebrates have a wide range of colors, from red to blue. In some species, the color of the animal is determined by the presence of a protein that binds biliverdin, the pigment of hemoglobin. This phenomenon is called chlorosis. In this study, we show that chlorosis has evolved multiple times during the evolutionary history of anurans. We also describe a new function for a member of the serpin superfamily, the largest and most ubiquitous group of protease inhibitors. Our results provide evidence of recurrent evolution of chlorosis, describe a biliverdin-binding protein in vertebrates, and introduce a function for a member of the serpin superfamily. Breast cancer is the most common cancer in women worldwide. The identification of factors that promote the growth of breast cancer cells in the presence of oxygen, which is the normal condition, is important for the development of new therapies. We report that hypoxia induces expression of a demethylase that increases the proportion of breast cancer cells that have the properties of cancer stem cells. This study may lead to the development of new therapies for breast cancer.

The Bible is the most widely read book in the world. The first pocket Bibles were made in the 13th century. The source of the parchment, often called “uterine vellum,” has been a long-standing controversy. Here, we report a simple and objective method to identify the animal origin of parchment. We found no evidence for the use of unexpected animals, but did identify the use of more than one mammal species in a single manuscript. These results suggest that ultrafine vellum does not necessarily derive from the use of abortive or newborn animals with ultrathin hides, but could equally well reflect a production process that allowed the skins of maturing animals of several species to be rendered into vellum of equal quality and fineness. The Permian-Triassic extinction is the most severe loss of marine and terrestrial biota in the last 542 My. The cause of the extinction is unknown, but the timing of the event, the carbon cycle, and the rate of evolution of life all depend on the accuracy of the age model. We present a precise age model for the extinction and its aftermath, which will allow a refined evaluation of the relative roles of rate-dependent processes contributing to the extinction. This will allow insight into postextinction ecosystem expansion, and establish an accurate time point for evaluating the plausibility of trigger and kill mechanisms. The spike glycoprotein of SARS-CoV-2 is the primary target of the immune response. We have determined the structure of the spike protein in complex with the human receptor, ACE2, and the human cellular protease, TMPRSS2. We find that the D614G mutation in the spike protein has little effect on the structure of the spike protein, but does affect the conformation of the spike protein. We show that the D614G mutant spike is more infectious in animal models. Our results suggest that the D614G mutation may increase the infectivity of SARS-CoV-2.

We consider repeated games with tail-measurable payoffs, i.e., when the payoffs depend only on what happens in the long run. We show that every repeated game with tail-measurable payoffs admits an ε-equilibrium, for every ε>0, provided that the set of players is finite or countably infinite and the action sets are finite. The proof relies on techniques from stochastic games and from alternating-move games with Borel-measurable payoffs.

COVID-19 has resulted in a staggering death toll in the United States. We estimate that the pandemic has resulted in a decline in life expectancy at birth of 1.13 y, lower than any year since 2003. The Black and Latino populations are estimated to experience declines in life expectancy at birth of 2.10 and 3.05 y, respectively, both of which are several times the 0.68-y reduction for Whites. Latinos, who have consistently experienced lower mortality than Whites, would see their more than 3-y survival advantage reduced to less than 1 y. These projections imply an increase of nearly 40% in the Black−White life expectancy gap, from 3.6 y to over 5 y. These findings underscore the need for urgent action to address structural inequalities that increase risk of exposure to COVID-19 and mortality risk for those infected.

The chemical properties of atoms are of fundamental importance in chemistry. In this work, we show that the chemical properties of atoms can be used to predict and explain the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This work is of fundamental importance, as it provides a predictive model for the behavior of chemical compounds under pressure. This model can be used to predict the behavior of exotic compounds under pressure, and it can also be used to rationalize the behavior of known compounds under pressure.

Fire is a key natural process in terrestrial ecosystems, but its role in climate change is poorly understood. We show that human ignitions and fire suppression have been the dominant driver of global fire activity over the last century. However, we also find that climate change has been a major driver of fire activity in the last century, and that climate change may reverse this trend in the future. This has implications for climate change mitigation and adaptation, as well as for the functioning of fire-dependent ecosystems.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes can be a critical factor in the establishment and maintenance of mutualisms. However, the mechanisms by which host organisms regulate the activities of their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, by a host organism is critical for the persistence of its luminescent symbiont. We also show that the catabolism of this glycan is required for the periodic acidification of the symbiont’s habitat, which enhances its capacity to produce bioluminescence. This study provides a mechanism by which host organisms can regulate the activities of their symbionts. It also suggests that other hosts may regulate the activities of their symbionts through the strategic provision of specific nutrients. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Text data are ubiquitous and increasingly important. However, it is difficult to identify the latent patterns in text data. We introduce a method to identify latent patterns in text data and represent documents as topic sequences. We apply our method to a prominent example of underutilized text: the US National Violent Death Reporting System. Our results provide a detailed quantitative picture of reporting about lethal violence and its gendered nature. Our method offers a flexible and broadly applicable approach to model topics in text data.

The second plague pandemic, which started with the arrival of the Black Death in Europe in the 14th century, lasted for more than four centuries. The origin of this disease is still a matter of debate. We show that the climate fluctuations that preceded the outbreaks of plague in European harbors were the main driver of the reintroduction of the bacterium into Europe. Our results suggest that the Black Death was not the result of a single introduction of Yersinia pestis, but rather the consequence of multiple introductions, each of which was followed by a long period of adaptation to the local climate.

Asteroids are a major component of the marine food web. In the past few years, a disease has emerged that has led to the mass mortality of these animals. We show that the disease is caused by a virus. We also show that the virus is widespread in the environment and that it has been present on the North American Pacific Coast for at least 72 y.

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML) is a highly heterogeneous disease, and the identification of new targets for therapy is urgently needed. Here we show that the IL1 receptor accessory protein (IL1RAP) is a promising target for AML therapy. We demonstrate that IL1RAP is expressed on candidate leukemic stem cells in the majority of AML patients and that monoclonal antibodies targeting IL1RAP have strong antileukemic effects in xenograft models of human AML. We also show that an IL1RAP-targeting antibody capable of blocking IL-1 signaling can suppress the proliferation of primary human AML cells. These results provide important evidence in support of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based treatment of AML. This study also provides a proof of principle for the use of IL1RAP as a target for antibody-based therapy of other diseases. (Show more)

Madagascar is a unique island in the Indian Ocean, with a unique history. We used a grid-based approach to sample the genomic diversity across the island. We find that Madagascar is a mosaic of African and Asian ancestry, with a recent settlement. However, the distribution of ancestry across the island reveals that the settlement was not homogeneous, suggesting that the settlement of Madagascar happened in several independent waves. In addition, we show that a few centuries are sufficient to produce detectable genetic structure in human populations. This study provides a unique view of the history of Madagascar. It also provides a framework to study the history of other islands in the Indian Ocean.

Bacteria have evolved small RNAs (sRNAs) to regulate numerous biological processes and stress responses. While sRNAs generally are considered to be “noncoding,” a few have been found to also encode a small protein. Here we describe one such dual-function RNA that modulates carbon utilization in Escherichia coli. The 164-nucleotide RNA was previously shown to encode a 28-amino acid protein (denoted AzuC). We discovered the membrane-associated AzuC protein interacts with GlpD, the aerobic glycerol-3-phosphate dehydrogenase, and increases dehydrogenase activity. Overexpression of the RNA encoding AzuC results in a growth defect in glycerol and galactose medium. The defect in galactose medium was still observed for a stop codon mutant derivative, suggesting a second role for the RNA. Consistent with this observation, we found that cadA and galE are repressed by base pairing with the RNA (denoted AzuR).
