The emergence of SARS-CoV-2 variants has raised concerns about the effectiveness of vaccines and treatments. To address this challenge, we developed a deep learning algorithm to improve the neutralizing activity of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants. Our algorithm can be used to optimize the antibody sequence to improve its binding affinity against multiple variants. We demonstrated the utility of our algorithm by improving the potency of an antibody against SARS-CoV-2 variants, including Delta. Our results highlight the potential of deep learning in antibody engineering and its application to the development of antibody drug candidates against emerging variants. This work may also provide a solution to the challenge of vaccine and treatment effectiveness against variants.

Crop experts are the backbone of the US agricultural system. They provide a wealth of information on the status of crops across the country, but this information is not used to its full potential. We show how to convert the original categorical crop ratings into a continuous probabilistic variable that can be used to monitor crop status and predict crop yields. We demonstrate that this approach can provide earlier and more precise predictions of crop yields than official USDA forecasts released midseason. Our results show the potential of harnessing the power of the “people as sensors” network to improve agricultural decision-making.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features within the brain.

Soil respiration is a major component of the global carbon cycle, and its response to climate change is of critical importance. However, despite decades of research, the response of soil respiration to warming remains unclear. Here, we present the results of the largest global synthesis of soil respiration, temperature, and moisture measurements to date. Our analysis reveals that soil respiration rates increase with soil temperature up to a threshold of ∼25 °C, above which respiration rates decrease with further increases in temperature. This consistent decrease in temperature sensitivity at higher temperatures demonstrates that colder regions will be considerably more responsive to increased ambient temperatures compared with warmer regions. Our results highlight the importance of including a wide range of biomes in future studies to improve our mechanistic understanding of how soil respiration responds to climate change. This information is critical to improving our ability to predict the response of the global carbon cycle to future climate change. (Show more)

The evolution of plastid genomes is a key component of the evolution of life on Earth. The transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is a major event in the evolution of life, and the molecular signature of this transition is still poorly understood. We present a model of the trajectory of plastid genome evolution during the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy. Our model is based on the assumption that the transition from autotrophy to heterotrophy is characterized by a gradual relaxation of functional constraints on the plastid genome. We show that the relaxation of functional constraints is linked to the establishment of a parasitic lifestyle. Our findings have implications for our understanding of the evolution of life on Earth. They also have implications for the evolution of plastid genomes in the context of the evolution of life on Earth.

The 2015–2017 Cape Town drought is a stark reminder of the impact of climate change on water security. We use a high-resolution large ensemble to quantify the contribution of anthropogenic climate change to the probability of occurrence of multiyear rainfall deficits in southwestern South Africa. We find that anthropogenic climate change increased the likelihood of the 2015–2017 rainfall deficit by a factor of five to six. The probability of such an event will increase from 0.7 to 25% by the year 2100 under an intermediate-emission scenario (Shared Socioeconomic Pathway 2-4.5) and to 80% under a high-emission scenario (SSP5-8.5). These results highlight the strong sensitivity of the drought risk in SSA to future anthropogenic emissions. This work is a first step towards quantifying the impact of climate change on water security in SSA. However, more research is needed to understand the impact of climate change on water resources in SSA. The discovery of quasicrystals has revolutionized condensed matter physics. However, the conditions under which they form are still poorly understood. Here, we report the discovery of a hitherto unknown composition of icosahedral quasicrystal in a sample of red trinitite, the first test explosion of a nuclear bomb. The discovery of this quasicrystal, with its unique history, demonstrates that quasicrystals can form under transient conditions and that the search for new quasicrystal-forming systems continues. Photosynthesis is the most important process on Earth. It is powered by the capture of solar radiation and its conversion to chemical energy. The conversion of the absorbed energy to chemical energy is mediated by the chlorophyll pigments. The biosynthesis of these pigments is among the most productive biological pathways on Earth. The formation of the fifth ring of the chlorophyll molecule, the isocyclic ring, has remained enigmatic for more than 60 y. This reaction is catalyzed by two unrelated enzymes using different chemistries. Here we show that the two enzymes are part of a larger family of enzymes, which we term cyclase proteins.

Neuroinflammation is a major pathological feature in neurodegenerative diseases. Neuroinflammation is associated with the activation of mitogen-activated protein kinase kinase kinase (MAP3K) ASK1. However, the roles of ASK1 in neuroinflammation remain unclear. In this study, we found that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation. ASK1 deficiency in microglia/macrophages ameliorated the disease severity in EAE. ASK1 deficiency in astrocytes was also associated with the exacerbation of disease. ASK1 deficiency in T cells and dendritic cells had no significant effects on EAE severity. Our findings suggest that ASK1 in microglia/macrophages plays a major role in the generation and maintenance of neuroinflammation, and ASK1 in astrocytes exacerbates neuroinflammation. These findings provide a rationale for the development of ASK1 inhibitors as a potential therapeutic strategy for neurodegenerative diseases. (PsycINFO Database Record

California is currently in the midst of a record-setting drought. We show that the probability of drought has increased substantially in the past two decades, and that this increase is largely attributable to human activities.

Autism is a complex neurodevelopmental disorder with a high heritability. Therefore, it is difficult to identify the causal genes and the causal pathways. In this study, we used a reversal-learning task to measure behavioral flexibility in Drosophila and determined the effects of loss-of-function mutations in multiple autism-risk gene homologs in flies. We found that mutations of five autism-risk gene homologs all led to a similar phenotype of behavioral inflexibility indicated by impaired reversal-learning. These reversal-learning defects resulted from the inability to forget or rather, rather, to activate Rac1 (Ras-related C3 botulinum toxin substrate 1)-dependent forgetting. Thus, behavior-evoked activation of Rac1-dependent forgetting has a converging function for autism-risk genes. This study provides a mechanistic understanding of the behavioral inflexibility in autism and may facilitate the development of new therapeutic strategies. This study also provides a useful model system for studying the role of forgetting in learning and memory. (PsycINFO Database Record

News media are increasingly focused on negative content. This work reports the results of a 17-country, 6-continent experiment that demonstrates the pervasiveness of negativity biases in the world’s news media. It also highlights the potential for more positive content to reduce the prevalence of negativity biases.

Stormorken syndrome is a rare disorder characterized by bleeding diathesis, thrombocytopenia, miosis, and tubular myopathy. Here, we report that mutations in the CRAC channel pore-forming protein STIM1 and ORAI1 are associated with Stormorken syndrome. We show that the mutations in STIM1 and ORAI1 result in gain- or gain-and-loss-of-function of the CRAC channel, respectively. Our findings expand our understanding of the molecular basis of Stormorken syndrome and suggest new therapeutic strategies for patients with this disorder. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Neurodegenerative diseases are characterized by the accumulation of misfolded proteins in the brain. These proteins aggregate and spread throughout the brain, causing damage to neurons. However, the mechanisms underlying this spreading are poorly understood. Here we use a fluorescently tagged polyglutamine-expanded form of human huntingtin to study the spreading of aggregates in the Drosophila brain. We show that aggregates accumulate at synaptic terminals and progressively spread throughout the brain. These aggregates are internalized and accumulate within other neurons. We also show that the release of aggregates requires fusion protein 1, demonstrating that active release and uptake of aggregates are important elements of spreading and disease progression. Our results provide insights into the mechanisms underlying the spreading of neurodegenerative proteins and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. Bats are increasingly accepted as potential reservoirs of many viruses that cause zoonotic disease outbreaks through spillover to other animals and humans. However, the factors that contribute to virus spillover from bats are very limited. Here, we identified and characterized an immunosuppressant protein (MTX) that is highly concentrated in the submandibular salivary gland of the bat, Myotis pilosus. This study provides deeper insight into immunologically privileged sites for microbial community residence in bats and supports the therapeutic potential of targeting MTX-LTA4H. This study also provides a deeper understanding of the role of MTX in the immune system of bats and its potential as a therapeutic target for the prevention and treatment of viral infections. These findings are of great significance for understanding the role of bats in the emergence of zoonotic diseases and for the development of antiviral strategies. (PsycINFO Database Record

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the most important metabolic pathways in cancer is the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway, which supports cell growth by providing the building blocks for DNA and RNA synthesis. Here we report the discovery of a small-molecule inhibitor of the one-carbon unit biosynthetic pathway. We show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of colon cancer xenografts in mice. We also show that this inhibitor is effective in blocking the growth of a subset of B-cell cancers, but paradoxically is ineffective in blocking the growth of a different subset of B-cell cancers. Thus, this inhibitor is a useful tool for the study of cancer metabolism, and may be useful in the treatment of cancer.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a devastating neurodegenerative disease with no known cause or cure. Here, we show that the proteins that form inclusions in the brain and spinal cord of ALS patients are supersaturated in motor neurons, but not in other cell types. This suggests that the presence of these proteins in inclusions is a consequence of a disease-related progressive collapse of protein homeostasis in motor neurons. This study provides a new perspective on the pathogenesis of ALS and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. (Show more)

Cold atoms are a versatile platform for exploring fundamental physics and for applications in quantum technologies. In this work, we present a 2D photonic crystal system for interacting with cold atoms. The photonic crystal can be used to control the interaction between atoms and light, and to engineer the properties of the atom–light interaction. The device can be fabricated from a 200-nm silicon nitride layer, and can be readily deployed to experiments for many-body physics with neutral atoms and engineering of exotic quantum matter. This work opens up a new avenue for the study of quantum many-body physics with neutral atoms. It also provides a platform for applications in quantum technologies.

The origin of the flowering plants is one of the most important events in the history of life. The study of the early evolution of the flowering plants is hampered by the lack of fossils. Here we present a detailed study of the early flowering plant Montsechia. The study of Montsechia raises questions about the very early divergence of the flowering plant clade and the role of aquatic habitats in the early evolution of flowering plants.

Parvoviruses are small, nonenveloped viruses that are ubiquitous in nature and can cause serious diseases in humans. The evolution of parvoviruses has been studied using genetic sequences from living species, but the evolution of the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses is unknown. Here we present 10 ancient parvovirus genomes from humans who lived ∼0.5 to ∼6.9 thousand years ago. We find that the most recent common ancestor of all parvoviruses lived ∼12.6 thousand years ago. We also find that the recombination event that formed the human parvovirus B19 occurred ∼5.0–6.8 thousand years ago. This study emphasizes the importance of ancient viral sequences for our understanding of virus evolution and phylogenetics. (Show more)

Sea level is rising, and it is rising quickly. This is a well-known fact. However, the rate of sea level rise is not constant. In fact, it is accelerating. This paper provides a new estimate of the rate of acceleration of sea level rise. We find that the rate of acceleration is not constant either. It is increasing. This is important because it means that the rate of sea level rise is not a constant, and therefore neither is the rate of climate change.

Pain is a common and costly problem. In this paper, we show that pain is not a universal phenomenon. It is not inevitable that pain will increase with age. In fact, pain is lower in the elderly than in midlife. We also show that the erosion of working-class life in America is reflected in the erosion of working-class pain.

The study of enzyme mechanisms is a central goal of structural biology. Here, we use NMR-assisted crystallography to provide a detailed, chemically detailed, three-dimensional picture of the tryptophan synthase α-aminoacrylate intermediate. This picture reveals the fate of the leaving group and the reaction pathway back to the preceding transition state. The study also highlights the importance of the cofactor and substrate in the reaction mechanism. This work demonstrates the power of NMR-assisted crystallography to provide mechanistic insight into enzyme mechanisms. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) is a severe disease with a high case fatality rate. There is a pressing need for the development of effective antiviral treatments. Here, we show that remdesivir, a broad-spectrum antiviral drug, is effective in preventing and treating MERS-CoV infection in a nonhuman primate model. This study supports the use of remdesivir in a clinical trial of MERS-CoV infection, and may also be considered for a wider range of coronaviruses, including the currently emerging novel coronavirus 2019-nCoV. This study also highlights the importance of early treatment with antiviral drugs in the context of MERS and other severe viral diseases. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The provision of nutrients to specific symbiotic microbes can be a critical factor in the establishment and maintenance of mutualisms. However, the mechanisms by which hosts regulate the activities of their symbionts are poorly understood. Here, we show that the provision of a single glycan, chitin, is sufficient to regulate the activities of the symbionts of a bioluminescent squid. We also show that the catabolism of chitin by the symbionts is required for the periodic acidification of the squid’s symbiotic crypts, which increases the availability of oxygen to the symbionts and enhances their luminescence. This study provides a mechanism by which hosts can regulate the activities of their symbionts. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Suspension rates in US schools have risen sharply in recent decades. This study shows that teachers can be encouraged to adopt a more empathic mindset about student misbehavior. This change in mindset, in turn, bolstered students’ respect for teachers and their motivation to behave well in class. These findings have implications for the design of effective school discipline policies.

DNA alkylation is a major cause of mutagenesis and genomic instability. However, the molecular mechanisms of alkylation-induced transcriptional stalling and mutagenesis remain unknown. In this work, we systematically investigated the impact of alkylation on transcription. We found that the transcription stalls at alkylated DNA template and that the stalling is exacerbated by the proofreading activity of RNA polymerase II. We also found that the transcription stalls at alkylated DNA template can be bypassed by the normal error-prone or error-free routes. Finally, we identified a minor-groove–sensing motif from pol II that is involved in modulating the translocation of alkylated DNA template. Taken together, this work provides important mechanistic insights into transcriptional stalling, lesion bypass, and mutagenesis of alkylated DNA lesions. Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) infects humans from zoonotic sources and causes severe pulmonary disease. Virions require spike (S) glycoproteins for binding to cell receptors and for catalyzing virus–cell membrane fusion. We found that the sequential proteolysis of MERS-CoV S proteins is required for efficient infection of human lung-derived cells. This requirement for sequential proteolysis correlated with S conformations during cell entry. Without the first cleavages, S proteins resisted cell receptor-induced conformational changes, which restricted the second, fusion-activating cleavages. Consistent with these findings, uncleaved viruses were less infectious to human airway epithelial and Calu3 cell cultures because they lacked sufficient endosomal fusion-activating proteases. Thus, by sensitizing viruses to receptor-induced conformational changes, the first S cleavages expand virus tropism to cell types that are relevant to lung infection, and therefore may be significant determinants of MERS-CoV virulence. © 2016, The Author(s). The food system is a major contributor to global warming and other environmental degradation. The food choices of the population have a large impact on this system. In this paper, we show that a simple change to catering practices can have a large impact on the proportion of meals that are vegetarian. This has the potential to make a significant contribution to the fight against climate change.

Cancer is a disease of the cell surface, and the surfaceome is the interface for the cell to engage the extracellular space. Here we apply a quantitative proteomics approach to reveal how the surfaceome is remodeled in a panel of six oncogenic cell lines. We find that each oncogene has somewhat different surfaceomes, but the functions of these proteins are harmonized by common biological themes including up-regulation of nutrient transporters, down-regulation of adhesion molecules and tumor suppressing phosphatases, and alteration in immune modulators. These studies provide a broad systems-level view of how specific driver oncogenes remodel the surfaceome and the glycoproteome in a cell autologous fashion, and suggest possible surface targets, and combinations thereof, for drug and biomarker discovery. This work is a significant step toward understanding the biology of the cell surface in cancer. © 2017, The Author(s).

The COVID-19 pandemic has led to a surge in interest in vote-by-mail programs. However, the effects of such a policy are unknown. In this paper, we provide a comprehensive design-based analysis of the effect of universal vote-by-mail on electoral outcomes. We find that universal vote-by-mail does not appear to affect either party’s share of turnout, does not appear to increase either party’s vote share, and modestly increases overall average turnout rates. All three conclusions support the conventional wisdom of election administration experts and contradict many popular claims in the media. Our results suggest that vote-by-mail programs are a safe and effective way to conduct elections during the pandemic.

The SARS-CoV-2 pandemic has had a devastating impact on the global population. The virus has been shown to evade the host immune response, and it is possible that this is due to the actions of accessory proteins. Here, we report the structure of SARS-CoV-2 ORF8, which is a rapidly evolving accessory protein. The structure reveals a unique dimerization interface that is specific to SARS-CoV-2. Cerebral edema is a potentially life-threatening illness. Here we show that hypobaric hypoxia induces cerebral edema and neuronal apoptosis in rats. We also show that hypoxia triggers cortical release of corticotrophin releasing factor (CRF), which acts on CRF receptor type 1 (CRFR1) to trigger signaling of cAMP/PKA in cortical astrocytes, leading to activation of aquaporin-4 (AQP4) and cerebral edema. These findings provide a molecular basis for the pathogenesis of cerebral edema and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. The world is full of associations. We want to know which ones are strong. Unfortunately, we can’t just measure the strength of every association. That would be like saying that we have measured the strength of every tree in the world. Instead, we must set a higher bar for declaring that an association is strong. This paper describes some recent developments in this area.

The generation of endothelial cells (ECs) is a critical step for the development of vascular networks. However, the minimum number of transcription factors that can directly induce ECs remains undefined. Here, we demonstrate that ets variant 2 (ETV2) alone can directly convert primary human adult skin fibroblasts into functional vascular endothelial cells (ETVECs). In coordination with endogenous FOXC2 in fibroblasts, transduced ETV2 elicits expression of multiple key endothelial development factors, including FLI1, ERG, and TAL1, and induces expression of endothelial functional molecules, including EGFL7 and von Willebrand factor. Consequently, ETVECs exhibits EC characteristics in vitro and forms mature functional vasculature in Matrigel plugs transplanted in NOD SCID mice. Our study indicates that the creation of ETVECs provides further understanding of human EC development induced by ETV2. This approach may be useful for the treatment of vascular disorders. The orphan receptor tyrosine kinases anaplastic lymphoma kinase (Alk) and leucocyte tyrosine kinase (Ltk) are implicated in cancer and other diseases. Here, we show that two other orphan RTKs, augmentor-α1, -α2, and -β, are ligands of Alk and Ltk. We also show that these ligands are essential for zebrafish pigmentation. These findings establish a physiological link between augmentor ligands and Ltk and demonstrate that augmentor ligands activate Ltk in a tissue-specific context to induce iridophore differentiation from neural crest-derived cells and pigment progenitor cells. This work provides a better understanding of the function of these orphan RTKs and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. Type 2 diabetes (T2D) is a complex disease with multiple molecular bases. In this study, we found that STING is required for β-cell function and insulin secretion. Our study provides a potential therapeutic target for T2D.

Influenza A viruses are the leading cause of human respiratory infections. They are divided into two groups, the human and avian influenza viruses. The avian viruses are the most likely candidates to cause a pandemic. The genome of the avian influenza viruses is divided into eight segments, which complicates the packaging process. Here, we identified a mechanism that favors the packaging of two viral RNA segments together. This mechanism is sequence specific and is not widely conserved among influenza A viruses. This mechanism might limit the reassortment of viral segments between divergent influenza A viruses. This study provides a better understanding of the packaging mechanism of influenza A viruses. It also provides a starting point for the development of new antiviral strategies. (Show more)

Atherosclerosis is a chronic inflammatory disease that leads to the development of atherosclerotic lesions. The underlying mechanisms are not fully understood. In this study, we found that the activation of YAP/TAZ by disturbed flow is critical for the development of atheroprone phenotypes and atherosclerotic lesion formation. Our results suggest that inhibition of YAP/TAZ activation is a promising therapeutic strategy for the treatment of atherosclerosis. This study also provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of YAP/TAZ in the development of atherosclerotic lesions and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for the treatment of atherosclerosis. Wildfire is a natural process that has been an integral part of the Earth system for millennia. However, in recent decades, the economic and ecological costs of wildfire have risen dramatically. In this study, we show that humans have expanded the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire in the United States. We also show that human-caused wildfires disproportionately occur in areas with higher fuel moisture, thereby helping to expand the geographic and seasonal extent of wildfire. Our results highlight the need for increased management of human-caused wildfires to reduce the risk of wildfire to ecosystems and communities.

Urban change is a complex process that is difficult to study. In this paper, we introduce a computer vision method to measure changes in the physical appearances of neighborhoods from time-series street-level imagery. We use this method to study the physical dynamics of five US cities. Our results provide support for three classical theories of urban change and illustrate the value of using computer vision methods and street-level imagery to understand the physical dynamics of cities. Our method can be used to study the physical dynamics of other cities and other types of urban change. We hope that our method will be useful to urban scholars and practitioners.

Natural repellents are an ecological method of pest control. However, their molecular targets in arthropods remain to be further elucidated. Here, we identified a scorpion transient receptor potential (sTRP1) channel that senses Cymbopogon-derived natural repellents, while remaining insensitive to the synthetic chemical pesticide DEET. This study sheds light on arthropod molecular targets of natural repellents, exemplifying the arthropod–plant adaptation. It should also help the rational design of insect control strategy and in conserving biodiversity. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

The recent outbreak of Zika virus (ZIKV) has been associated with neurological complications and fetal abnormalities. The mechanisms of disease are not fully understood, but the role of the host immune response is likely important. Here we present a mathematical model of ZIKV infection in a nonhuman primate model. We show that the model is able to capture the main features of the disease, including the rapid rise in viremia, the presence of a short eclipse phase, and the role of the immune response in the decline of viremia. We also provide estimates of the basic reproductive number and the rate of viral production. Finally, we assess the potential effect of an antiviral treatment and show that the model can be used to predict the effect of the treatment on the course of the disease. (Show more)

Coral reefs are among the most valuable ecosystems on the planet. However, they are under threat from a variety of environmental stressors. In this study, we show that the breakdown of the coral–algal symbiosis is driven by altered nutrient cycling during heat stress. This process is a key driver of the functional breakdown of the symbiosis and, ultimately, of the breakdown of the coral–algal partnership. Our results provide a missing link in our understanding of the environmental drivers of bleaching and may ultimately help us to preserve this unique ecosystem.

The intestinal epithelium is a critical barrier that protects the host from the environment. In this study, we show that the loss of BMP signaling in the intestinal epithelium leads to the development of intestinal tumors. These tumors activate JNK signaling, which in turn triggers a dysbiotic microbiome and a regenerative response. The dysregulated microbiome and regenerative response, in turn, promote tumor growth. Our experiments identify a JNK-dependent feedback amplification loop between intestinal tumors and the microbiome. They also highlight the importance of controlling the activity level of JNK signaling to maintain epithelial barrier function and host–microbe homeostasis. Our work provides a mechanistic understanding of the role of the microbiome in tumorigenesis and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Chemotherapy is a major treatment for breast cancer, but many patients do not respond well to this therapy. In this study, we found that the expression of the type I tyrosine kinase-like orphan receptor ROR1 increased in breast cancer cells following treatment with chemotherapy. We also found that ROR1 expression was associated with the expression of genes induced by the activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or B lymphoma Mo-MLV insertion region 1 homolog (BMI1). Finally, we found that targeting ROR1 with the humanized anti-ROR1 monoclonal antibody cirmtuzumab was associated with reduced expression of genes associated with breast cancer stemness, reduced activation of Rho-GTPases, Hippo-YAP/TAZ, or BMI1, and reduced capacity of breast cancer PDXs to metastasize or reengraft Rag2−/−γc−/− mice. These results indicate that targeting ROR1 may improve the response to chemotherapy of patients with breast cancer. (Read more)

The start of Southern Hemisphere deglaciation is often ascribed to a sudden poleward shift in the Southern Hemisphere westerlies and subsequent climate impacts. We show that a unique, ∼192-y series of halogen-rich volcanic eruptions at the start of deglaciation is likely to have led to stratospheric ozone depletion, which in turn likely caused a strong climate response. This response, in turn, likely led to the deglaciation.

Freshwater fisheries are a critical source of food, recreation, and commerce for hundreds of millions of people around the world. However, they are often overlooked in conservation and management efforts. We provide a global map of riverine fisheries, which reveals that most catches come from rivers with high levels of human stress. We also show that inland fisheries are a critical source of protein for the poor and undernourished. At the same time, the high dependence of poor people on inland fisheries in regions where rivers are already degraded by other stressors underscores the need for improved management. Our data can be used to inform conservation and management of freshwater fisheries and to prioritize areas for investment in food security. This approach can help ensure that the benefits of fisheries are equitably shared and sustainably maintained for future generations.

The development of inherently safe energy devices is a key challenge. The energy density and the selection of negative electrode materials are significantly limited in aqueous Li-ion batteries. Herein, a type of a negative electrode material (i.e., LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2) is proposed for high-energy aqueous Li-ion batteries. The unique nanosized and metastable characters of Mo-based oxide are the key to achieve a large capacity and a low operating potential without triggering decomposition of water. A full cell consisting of Li1.05Mn1.95O4/Li9/7Nb2/7Mo3/7O2 presents high energy density of 107 W ⋅ h ⋅ kg−1 as the maximum value in 21 m LiTFSA aqueous electrolyte, and 73% in capacity retention is achieved after 2,000 cycles. Furthermore, hard X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy study reveals that a protective surface layer is formed at the surface of the negative electrode, by which the high-energy and durable aqueous batteries are realized with LixNb2/7Mo3/7O2. The ability to regenerate after injury is a critical feature of the adult nervous system. In the past decade, we have made significant progress in understanding the molecular mechanisms of regeneration in the C. elegans nervous system. In this study, we extend these findings to the mammalian nervous system, revealing a previously unknown form of regeneration that is independent of the canonical MAPK signaling pathway. This study provides a unique platform for the discovery of genes that regulate regeneration in the adult mammalian nervous system.

Recombination is the process by which the genetic material of a cell is broken and rewired. It is essential for the proper development of the organism and the survival of the species. In this paper, we describe the distribution of recombination across the genome of a flowering plant. We find that hotspots of recombination are interspersed among cold regions, and that the pattern of recombination is similar to that in yeast and in mice. This suggests that recombination initiation and polarity may have been conserved in eukaryotes over a long period of evolution.

The brain is organized in functional networks, which are thought to be involved in the generation of cognitive functions. However, the functional significance of the brain’s network organization is still unclear. Here, we show that the brain’s network organization can be directly measured by using a nonfluctuating brain imaging technique, and that this organization is altered in health and disease. This technique can be used to study the functional significance of the brain’s network organization.

RNA modifications are important for gene expression. In bacteria, the most common modification is the addition of nicotinamide-adenine dinucleotide (NAD+) to the 5′ end of some RNAs. In this study, we show that this modification also occurs on RNAs in eukaryotes. We also show that the 5′ NAD+ cap is not found on all RNAs, but only on subsets of mRNAs. This suggests that the 5′ NAD+ cap may have a role in regulating gene expression in eukaryotes.

The study of the long-term effects of intensive diabetes therapy on the prevention of microvascular complications is a major challenge in the field. We show that epigenetic DNA methylation differences at specific loci in blood cells persist for several years after the end of the Diabetes Control and Complications Trial (DCCT) and are associated with glycemia. These results support an epigenetic explanation for metabolic memory and may help to elucidate the mechanisms of action of intensive therapy. This study also provides a resource for future studies on the role of DNA-me in the prevention of microvascular complications.

Triple-negative breast cancer (TNBC) is the most aggressive subtype of breast cancer. In this study, we show that the expression of the protein, fibrous sheath interacting protein 1 (FSIP1), is associated with poor prognosis in TNBC patients. We also show that FSIP1 is a potential therapeutic target in TNBC and that it is associated with drug sensitivity. Our findings may aid in the design of TNBC therapies. (Show more)

Alcohol dependence is a chronic disease with a high prevalence and a high mortality rate. The present study shows that the gut barrier is altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the development of psychological symptoms. The gut microbiota is also altered in alcohol dependence, which may be related to the composition of the gut barrier. Thus, the gut microbiota seems to be a previously unidentified target in the management of alcohol dependence.

The flavor of tomato fruit is a complex mixture of volatile chemicals. These volatiles are produced during fruit ripening, and the content of many of these compounds varies widely among different tomato species. In this study, we identified a gene essential for the production of a large number of these compounds. We show that this gene catalyzes the biosynthesis of a unique class of nitrogenous volatiles, and that this pathway is evolutionarily conserved in other plants. This work provides a major advance in our understanding of the biosynthesis of tomato flavor, and will be of interest to researchers in the fields of plant biology, flavor chemistry, and biotechnology. Biodiversity loss and global warming are two of the most profound threats to the functioning of ecosystems. However, these factors are most frequently investigated separately, ignoring the potential for synergistic effects. Here we show that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning is sensitive to changes in temperature. We found that the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning becomes steeper as temperatures deviate from ambient conditions, meaning that more species are required to maintain ecosystem functioning under thermal stress. This result is driven by two processes linked to the thermal tolerance curves of taxa. First, more diverse communities have a greater chance of including species with thermal traits that enable them to maintain productivity as temperatures shift from ambient conditions. Second, we found a pronounced increase in the contribution of complementarity to the net biodiversity effect at high and low temperatures, indicating that changes in species interactions played a critical role in mediating the impacts of temperature change on the relationship between biodiversity and ecosystem functioning. Our results highlight that if biodiversity loss occurs independently of species’ thermal tolerance traits, then the additional impacts of environmental warming will result in sharp declines in ecosystem function. This study highlights the importance of considering the combined effects of biodiversity loss and environmental warming on ecosystem functioning. (Show more)

The medial entorhinal cortex (MEC) is a critical hub of the hippocampal circuit. It is thought to create a map of local space, based on the activity of grid, head-direction (HD), border, and object-vector (OV) cells. However, the anatomical organization of these cell types is debated. Here, we used a portable two-photon microscope to record the activity of neurons in MEC during free-running behavior. We found that grid cells are anatomically distinct from border, HD, and OV cells. These data suggest that grid cell networks might be largely distinct from those of border, HD, and OV cells. Our findings have implications for understanding the function of MEC in navigation. This article is protected by copyright. All rights reserved.

Flowering is a complex process that is regulated by a variety of environmental and developmental cues. In this study, we show that the flowering signal FLOWERING LOCUS T (FT) can be a regulator of flowering in a host–parasite interaction. We demonstrate that FTs can function as an important interplant flowering signal in host–dodder interactions. The unique means of flowering regulation of dodder illustrates how regressive evolution, commonly found in parasites, may facilitate the physiological synchronization of parasite and host, here allowing the C. australis parasite to time reproduction exactly with that of their hosts, likely optimizing parasite fitness. This study provides a unique example of how a parasite may have evolved to synchronize its reproduction with that of its host. © 2016, The Author(s). All rights reserved.

The dopamine system of the brain is critical to movement and motivation. We show that striatonigral fibers originating in striosomes form highly unusual bouquet-like arborizations that target bundles of ventrally extending dopamine-containing dendrites and clusters of their parent nigral cell bodies. These clustered cell bodies in turn project to the striatum as part of the classic nigrostriatal pathway. Thus, these striosome–dendron bouquets likely represent subsystems with the nigro–striato–nigral loop that are affected in human disorders including Parkinson’s disease. Given evidence that striosomes receive input from cortical regions related to the control of mood and motivation and that they link functionally to reinforcement and decision-making, the striosome–dendron bouquets could be critical to dopamine-related function in health and disease. We all have a sense of when two people are “clicking.” But how do we know when two people are “clicking”? We asked people to talk with each other and rate their felt connection. We found that the speed at which people responded to each other was a robust predictor of felt connection. Within conversations, connected moments had faster response times than less-connected moments. This effect was determined primarily by partner responsivity: People felt more connected to the degree that their partner responded quickly to them rather than by how quickly they responded to their partner. Together, these findings suggest that response times comprise a robust and sufficient signal of whether two minds “click.”

The sinoatrial node (SAN) is the natural pacemaker of the heart. SAN cells are responsible for generating the heart rate and are therefore critical for the regulation of heart rate in response to changes in blood pressure and volume. However, the mechanisms that govern SAN automaticity are not fully understood. Here, we report that stromal interaction molecule 1 (STIM1) is a key regulator of SAN automaticity. We show that STIM1 is selectively expressed in the specialized cardiomyocytes of the SAN, and its deletion in mice results in a reduction in the content of sarcoplasmic reticulum Ca2+ stores and a loss of SAN automaticity. These studies reveal that STIM1 is a multifunctional regulator of Ca2+ dynamics in SAN cells that links store content with electrical events occurring in the plasma membrane, thereby contributing to automaticity of the SAN. This study provides insights into the mechanisms that govern SAN function and may lead to the development of new therapeutic strategies for heart failure. (Show more)

Silicon (Si) is an essential element for plant growth and development. However, its function in plant defense against insect herbivores has not been well characterized. In this study, we show that Si pretreatment enhances rice resistance against the rice leaffolder, a key insect pest of rice, and that this effect is associated with an increase in jasmonate (JA) levels and defense gene expression. Our results suggest that Si and JA interact to promote plant defense against insect herbivores. This study provides a better understanding of the role of Si in plant defense and may lead to the development of Si-based strategies for insect pest management. (Show more)

The role of tetrahydrobiopterin in lipid metabolism is not well understood. Here we show that tetrahydrobiopterin is essential for the activity of alkylglycerol monooxygenase, which is an enzyme involved in ether lipid metabolism. We also show that alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity is important for the activation of macrophages. Our results reveal a central role of tetrahydrobiopterin and alkylglycerol monooxygenase in ether lipid metabolism of murine macrophages and reveal that alteration of alkylglycerol monooxygenase activity has a profound impact on the lipidome also beyond the class of ether lipids. Our findings may have implications for the treatment of phenylketonuria and other diseases.

Language is a complex system that involves the integration of information over time. Here we propose a computational model of memory in the brain that is based on the adaptive changes in the excitability of neurons. This mechanism is sensitive to context and serial order, and it can be used to bind linguistic features over time. This model provides a neurobiological substrate for the binding of linguistic features within the brain.

Plants are sessile organisms and are unable to move to avoid toxic stimuli. Thus, they are dependent on the delivery of biomolecules to the cell for survival. In this work, we demonstrate that DNA nanostructures can be used to deliver biomolecules across the cell wall of plants. We show that the size, shape, compactness, stiffness, and attachment location of the DNA nanostructures are important design parameters for the delivery and gene silencing efficiency. This work establishes the feasibility of DNA nanostructures for biomolecule delivery to plants and also details the design parameters of importance for gene silencing mechanisms. This work is expected to be useful for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to plants for the development of new crops and the improvement of existing crops. This work also provides a platform for the development of DNA nanostructures for the delivery of biomolecules to other organisms.

Nutrient pollution from small tributaries is a growing concern for coastal ecosystems worldwide. However, our understanding of the relative importance of small tributaries is limited by the lack of data. Here, we present a snapshot of nutrient inputs from nearly all tributaries of Lake Michigan, the world’s fifth largest freshwater lake by volume. We find that small tributaries deliver a disproportionately large amount of nutrients to the lake, especially in the form of dissolved inorganic nutrients. This suggests that small tributaries may be a significant source of coastal nutrient pollution. Our findings highlight the need to expand efforts to manage nutrient pollution from small tributaries to protect valuable nearshore ecosystems.

We study the dynamics of a simple chemical network in a thermodynamic environment that is only available to a small subset of chemical concentrations. We find that the system exhibits a strong tendency to concentrate in a small number of states that extremize the environmental forcing. We discuss the implications of this behavior for the evolution of complex systems.

Autoimmune encephalitis is a rare disorder that can cause seizures and other paroxysmal symptoms. The mechanisms underlying these paroxysms are poorly understood. Here we show that the presence of an antibody against a specific type of glutamate receptor can change the dynamics of the brain, making it more susceptible to paroxysmal symptoms. This mechanism may be relevant to a large number of autoimmune encephalitis cases, and may be a useful target for treatment. This work offers insights into the mechanisms of autoimmune encephalitis and may be relevant to other disorders in which the immune system attacks the brain. This article is protected by copyright. The Earth system is currently undergoing a rapid climate change. To understand the potential for future abrupt climate change, it is important to understand the history of abrupt climate change in the past. Here, we present a case study of an abrupt climate change that occurred ∼304 Ma. We show that this event was associated with a doubling of atmospheric CO2 and a biodiversity nadir. We also show that this event was linked to an increase in nutrient flux and thermocline stratification. These results provide insights into the potential for future abrupt climate change. The Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) is the most widely used certification scheme for palm oil. We show that RSPO certification is associated with reduced deforestation in Indonesia, the world’s leading producer of palm oil. However, certification had no causal impact on forest loss in peatlands or active fire detection rates. Broader adoption of certification in forested regions, strict requirements to avoid all peat, and routine monitoring of clearly defined forest cover loss in certified and RSPO member-held plantations appear necessary if the RSPO is to yield conservation and climate benefits from reductions in tropical deforestation. Our results highlight the importance of certification in reducing tropical deforestation, but also the need for more stringent requirements to avoid forest loss in noncertified areas. The exocyst complex is a protein complex that regulates the last steps of exocytosis. In humans, its dysfunction is correlated with several significant diseases, such as diabetes and cancer progression. In plants, the exocyst complex is essential for the proper functioning of the plant cell. However, the study of the dynamic regulation of the exocyst-related processes using mutants in genetically tractable organisms such as Arabidopsis thaliana is limited by the severity of phenotypes. We discovered that the small molecule Endosidin2 (ES2) binds to the EXO70 (exocyst component of 70 kDa) subunit of the exocyst complex, resulting in inhibition of exocytosis and endosomal recycling in both plant and human cells and enhancement of plant vacuolar trafficking. This study provides a valuable tool in studying exocytosis regulation and a potentially new target for drugs aimed at addressing human disease. (Show more)

Sex determination is a fundamental process in biology, and the evolution of sex determination is a major topic of study. In many vertebrates, sex is determined by a single gene, but in others, multiple genes interact to produce multiple genotypic sexes. Here we investigate the effects of multiple interacting sex determination alleles in a fish species. We find that the modularity of secondary sexual characteristics produced by multiple interacting sex determination alleles can provide context for understanding the evolutionary causes and consequences of maintenance, gain, or loss of sex determination alleles in populations. Our results suggest that the maintenance of multiple genotypic sexes may be a common evolutionary outcome of the evolution of multiple sex determination alleles. The retina is a highly oxidative tissue that is challenged by the accumulation of reactive oxygen species-generating adducts of vitamin A. We sought to understand how the levels of the intracellular iron (Fe) that supports redox active energy and electron transfer impact the retina. We found that Fe levels in the retina are tightly regulated and that Fe accumulation promotes the oxidation and degradation of a class of adducts that are implicated in the loss of photoreceptor cells. These findings have implications for the treatment of retinal diseases and for the development of strategies to protect the retina from oxidative stress. (Read more)

Predators are the foundation of all food webs, and the evolution of predator specialization has been considered an evolutionary dead end. Here we show that siphonophores, a group of pelagic predators, can evolve into generalists and that specialists on one prey type can evolve into specialists on other prey types. Our results suggest that shifts between prey types are linked to shifts in the morphology, mode of evolution, and evolutionary correlations of tentilla and their nematocysts. These findings contribute to understanding how specialization and morphological evolution have shaped present-day food webs.

The evolution of the human hand is a key area of research in human evolutionary biology. Despite the discovery of relatively complete hands from two early hominin species (Ardipithecus ramidus and Australopithecus sediba) and partial hands from another (Australopithecus afarensis), fundamental questions remain about the evolution of the human hand. These questions are driven by the paucity of hand fossils in the hominin fossil record between 800,000 and 1.8 My old, a time interval well documented for the emergence and subsequent proliferation of Acheulian technology. We show that the third metacarpal styloid process was present ∼1.42 Mya in an East African hominin from Kaitio, West Turkana, Kenya. This fossil thus provides the earliest unambiguous evidence for the evolution of a key shared derived characteristic of modern human and Neandertal hand morphology and suggests that the distinctive complex of radial carpometacarpal joint features in the human hand arose early in the evolution of the genus Homo and probably in Homo erectus sensu lato.

Cancer is a disease of uncontrolled cell growth. One of the most important factors that determines the growth of a tumor is the availability of nutrients. In this study, we show that a small-molecule inhibitor of two enzymes that convert nutrients into important building blocks of the cell, we found that it blocks the growth of colon cancer.

The world is facing a food and nutrition crisis. In this study, we show that deforestation can have a negative impact on people’s diets. This study has important implications for policy makers given that forests are largely overlooked in strategies to improve nutrition, but offer potential “win–wins” in terms of meeting nutrition goals as well as conservation and environmental goals. This study also provides a model for how to conduct research in a developing country, including the use of a causal modeling approach to test causal hypotheses. This approach can be used to test a wide range of hypotheses in the social sciences.

Modern agriculture is a major driver of the global food production, but it comes at a cost of soil degradation. We show that the increase in mechanization has led to higher vehicle weights that have propagated into deeper soil layers and now exceed safe mechanical limits for soil ecological functioning. We developed a global map for delineating subsoil compaction susceptibility based on estimates of mechanization level, mean tractor size, soil texture, and climatic conditions. The alarming trend of chronic subsoil compaction risk over 20% of arable land, with potential loss of productivity, calls for a more stringent design of farm machinery that considers intrinsic subsoil mechanical limits. As the total weight of modern harvesters is now approaching that of the largest animals that walked Earth, a paradox emerges of potential prehistoric subsoil compaction. We hypothesize that unconstrained roaming of sauropods would have had similar adverse effects on land productivity as modern farm vehicles, suggesting that ecological strategies for reducing subsoil compaction, including fixed foraging trails, must have guided these prehistoric giants. This hypothesis calls for a reexamination of the ecological history of sauropods.
